newsitem.title: USA: Gasoline prices drop on import talk.
newsitem.headline: Gasoline prices drop on import talk.

text.p: Gasoline futures prices in New York dropped sharply Thursday as talk of imports from Europe arriving on top of ample U.S. stocks fuelled concerns of oversupply, traders said.
"It's a combination of imports when we have ample supply, and the gasoline season being now over," said Gerald Samuels, managing director of ARB Oil.
Gasoline for October delivery fell 1.74 cents to 61.32 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) after falling as low as 60.40 cents during the day.

Gasoline demand traditionally peaks during the summer, and inventory draws during the season were considered lackluster by traders. Meanwhile, shipping sources have noticed a sharp increase in charters for gasoline shipments from Europe to the United States this month.
But motorists may not soon see lower prices at the pump.
The American Automile Association (AAA) said Tuesday that retail gasoline pump prices edged up in September, halting a three-month slide.

In its Sept. 17 Fuel Gauge report, AAA said self-serve regular unleaded gasoline rose to an average $1.255 per gallon this month, up 0.2 cent from August. But the price was still 8.7 cents above year-ago levels.
In other NYMEX trading on Thursday, October crude oil fell 35 cents to $23.54 a barrel and October heating oil slipped 1.10 cent to 66.77 cents a gallon on profit-taking.
